content.webTitle: Victorian authorities defend Wye River backburn days before 116 houses razed

fields.headline: Victorian authorities defend Wye River backburn days before 116 houses razed
fields.bodyText: Victorian fire authorities have defended a decision to conduct a backburn near the Wye River bushfire, three days before the fire destroyed 116 houses in the holiday town and nearby Separation creek. The emergency management commissioner, Craig Lapsley, said it would have been “riskier not to undertake the backburn” and said it was the fire caused by lightning strike that spread and destroyed homes. “The operational decision to use fire to control the Wye River-Jamieson track fire was not taken lightly,” Lapsley said on Wednesday evening. “The decision to burn out unburnt fuels adjacent to the original fire was considered an appropriate strategy after the fire could not be controlled ahead of forecast fire danger days.” Lapsley’s comments were in response to a story in Fairfax Media that said leaked documents from the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning showed the backburning operation, including the use of aerial incendiary balls, was approved despite warnings that it could cause a much larger fire. The original fire, called the Jamieson track fire, was sparked by twin lightning strikes on 19 December. The backburning operation began on 22 December, three days before extreme fire conditions on Christmas Day saw the fire grow to 2,200ha and wipe out a third of Wye River. A report from 23 December said firefighters had “extended the fire out from dense bushland to the Great Ocean Road to make attacking the edge of it easier” before conditions worsened. Lapsley said the backburning operation was conducted to “reduce intensity and fire spread”. “Burning out in a forest is a normal method of control, however this was complex and challenging to achieve in such a dry and inaccessible forest,” he said. “The risks were understood, and it was judged it would be riskier not to undertake the backburn.” Lapsley said the communities were told about the decision to conduct a backburn and it was a factor in putting evacuation plans in place, but said: “The fire which ran under strong winds on Christmas Day came from the area of the original lightning strike.” The Victorian environment minister, Lisa Neville, told ABC radio on Thursday that she was “disappointed in the report that was published today”, adding: “These high-risk strategies have helped control and contain this fire.” A spokeswoman for Neville said the decision to undertake the burn, and every other aspect of the fire, would be reviewed and a report would be produced by the inspector-general for emergency management. “This was an operational decision made by firefighters who have worked incredibly hard trying to get this fire under control,” the spokeswoman said. “This fire was in deep terrain and could not be extinguished. A decision was made by the incident controller, to conduct a burn-out when conditions were milder and before that every option to control the fire was taken before the burn-out decision was made.” The United Firefighters Union (UFU) and the Institute of Foresters of Australia have both criticised the management of the Wye River fire and called for an independent inquiry. Peter Marshall, secretary of the UFU, said the inquiry was beyond the resources of the inspector-general and should be conducted by the state coroner. The Coroners Act includes powers to investigate fires, even where no death has occurred. “Wye River residents are entitled to an independent coronial inquiry,” Marshall said.
